Context:
Program Name: American Sign Language and Deaf Studies
Code: C114
Credential: Ontario College Certificate
Method of Study: Full-time
Duration: 1 year (2 semesters)
Starting Months: September
Domestic Tuition: $4,152.00
International Tuition: $18,284.00
Centre: Community Services & Early Childhood
School: Deaf & Deafblind Studies
Location: St. James Campus
Program Description: A hybrid program providing intensive training in American Sign Language (ASL) and English for both Deaf and non-deaf students, including an orientation to Deaf culture and current social issues affecting Deaf people.
Program Availability:
- Fall 2024: Open (Domestic and International)
- Winter 2025: Not Available (Domestic and International)
- Spring 2025: Not Available (Domestic and International)
Related Programs: Honours Bachelor of Interpretation (ASL – English) (C302), Practical Nursing (PN) (S121)

Context:
The American Sign Language and Deaf Studies program at George Brown College does not have a formal field placement requirement. Students will have opportunities to practice through simulation and in-person experiences in the classroom. This program does not prepare students to be ASL-English Interpreters, Deaf Culture Instructors, or ASL Instructors. Graduates of this program may apply to the Honours Bachelor of Interpretation (American Sign Language – English) (C302) program at George Brown College or similar programs at other colleges if they wish to become American Sign Language-English Interpreters.

Career opportunities for individuals with ASL skills include health-care, business, educational and social service settings. Fluency in ASL is an asset for anyone who interacts with members of the Deaf community or the general public. To broaden employment prospects, students can combine this ASL certificate program with early childhood education, teaching, nursing, counselling, communications and law, other diplomas and degrees.

Required courses for this program include English Foundations for ASL Students (COMM 1022), Introduction to Anti-Oppressive Practice (SIGN 1056), ASL Immersion I (SIGN 1057), ASL Seminar I (SIGN 1058), Signed Language Communities (SIGN 1063), and ASL Immersion II (SIGN 1064).

Graduates of this program may also apply to George Brown's Deafblind & Intervenor Studies (C158) one-year certificate program. They may also apply to programs at George Brown College or similar programs at other colleges to further pursue a non-related career.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/American Sign Language and Deaf Studies Program C114 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
Programs Offered:
- SIGN 1064: ASL Immersion II
- SIGN 1065: ASL Seminar II
- COMM 2000: Communicating Across Contexts

Courses:
- ASL Immersion II (SIGN 1064)
- ASL Seminar II (SIGN 1065)
- Communicating Across Contexts (COMM 2000)

Program Learning Outcomes:
1. The graduate has reliably demonstrated the ability to communicate effectively in oral and written English.
2. The graduate can express and receive messages accurately in routine conversations using American Sign Language.
3. The graduate has basic knowledge of Deaf culture, the Deaf community, and the interpreter profession.

Tuition & Fees:
- Domestic Tuition (for programs starting in Fall 2023): $4,152.00 *
- International Tuition (for programs starting in Fall 2024): $18,284.00 **
- Additional Costs: varies based on program

Financial Assistance:
- The program is approved for OSAP funding

Admission Requirements:
- Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent
- Grade 12 English (C or U)
- Mature students may take the Admissions Assessment for English OR consider upgrading to achieve the credit(s) needed in English.

* Fees are subject to change and do not include books, which are to be purchased by students separately.
** Tuition fees are also subject to board approval. Material, student service and ancillary fees are estimated based on prior years and are subject to change without notice.
